item.title: About
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: This is an example of a page. Unlike posts, which are displayed on your blog’s front page in the order they’re published, pages are better suited for more timeless content that you want to be easily accessible, like your About or Contact information. Click the Edit link to make changes to this page or add another page.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: This is your very first post. Click the Edit link to modify or delete it, or start a new post. If you like, use this post to tell readers why you started this blog and what you plan to do with it. Happy blogging!

item.title: My First Choropleth: Unemployment May 2014
item.dc:creator: khasachi

item.title: U.S. Unemployment Rates, 2000-2013
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded:
D3: Setting path fills dynamically to generate a choropleth svg { font: 10px sans-serif; } .points { fill: red; } .caption { font-weight: bold; } .key path { display: none; } .key line { stroke: #000; shape-rendering: crispEdges; } .key text { font-size: 10px; } .tooltip { position: absolute; text-align: center; width: 60px; height: 12px; padding: 8px; font: 10px sans-serif; background: #ddd; border: solid 1px #aaa; border-radius: 8px; pointer-events: none; } p.yr2000 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-bottom:0px; cursor:pointer; } p.yr2001 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; cursor:pointer; } p.yr2002 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-bottom:0px; } p.yr2003 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2004 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2005 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2006 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2007 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2008 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2009 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2010 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2011 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2012 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } p.yr2013 {font: 10px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; } .titlestuff {font: 11px sans-serif; padding-top: 0px; font-weight: bold; } div.years {background-color:yellow; }

<!--

2000, U.S. 4.0%

2001, U.S. 4.7%

2002, U.S. 5.8%

2003, U.S. 5.8%

2004, U.S. 5.8%

2005, U.S. 5.8%

--> //Width and height var w = 500; var h = 500; var formatPercent = d3.format(".0%"); var maxscale = 7; //Define map projection var projection = d3.geo.albersUsa() .translate([w/2, h/2]) .scale([800]); //Define path generator var path = d3.geo.path() .projection(projection); //Define quantize scale to sort data values into buckets of color var qrange = function(max, num) { var a = []; for (var i=0; i<num; i++) { a.push(i*max/num); } return a; } var color = d3.scale.quantize() .domain([0.0,0.10]) .range(["#f2f0f7", "#dadaeb", "#bcbddc", "#9e9ac8", "#807dba", "#6a51a3", "#4a1486"]); //Colors taken from colorbrewer.js, included in the D3 download //Create SVG element var svg = d3.select(".post-58 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-uncategorized") .append("svg") .attr("width", w) .attr("height", h); //Load in agriculture data var csving = d3.csv("http://www.khasachi.com/wppost/unemployment2000.csv", function(data) { //Set input domain for color scale //color.domain([ // d3.min(data, function(d) { return d.value; }), // d3.max(data, function(d) { return d.value; }) //]); //Load in GeoJSON data d3.json("http://www.khasachi.com/wppost/usstates.json", function(json) { //Merge the ag. data and GeoJSON //Loop through once for each ag. data value for (var i = 0; i < data.length; i++) { //Grab state name var dataState = data[i].state; //Grab data value, and convert from string to float var dataValue = parseFloat(data[i].value); //Find the corresponding state inside the GeoJSON for (var j = 0; j < json.features.length; j++) { var jsonState = json.features[j].properties.name; if (dataState == jsonState) { //Copy the data value into the JSON json.features[j].properties.value = dataValue; //Stop looking through the JSON break; } } } //Bind data and create one path per GeoJSON feature var temp = svg.selectAll("path") .data(json.features) .enter() .append("path") .attr("d", path) .style("fill", function(d) { //Get data value var value = d.properties.value; if (value) { //If value exists… return color(value); } else { //If value is undefined… return "#ccc"; } }) console.log(temp) temp.on("mouseover", function(d) { var xPosition = d3.mouse(this)[0]; var yPosition = d3.mouse(this)[1] - 30; svg.append("text") .attr("id", "tooltip") .attr("x", xPosition) .attr("y", yPosition) .attr("text-anchor", "middle") .attr("font-family", "sans-serif") .attr("font-size", "11px") .attr("font-weight", "bold") .attr("fill", "black") .text(d.properties.name + ", " + d3.round(d.properties.value *100, 1) + "%" ); d3.select(this) .style("fill", "#509e2f"); }) .on("mouseout", function(d) { d3.select("#tooltip").remove(); d3.select(this) .transition() .duration(250) .style("fill", function(d) { //Get data value var value = d.properties.value; if (value) { //If value exists… return color(value); } else { //If value is undefined… return "#ccc"; } }); }) var x = d3.scale.linear() .domain([0, 0.12]) .range([0, 200]); var xAxis = d3.svg.axis() .scale(x) .orient("bottom") .tickSize(14) .tickValues(qrange(color.domain()[1], color.range().length)) .tickFormat(function(d) { return formatPercent(d); }); var g = svg.append("g") .attr("class", "key") .attr("transform", "translate( 50," + h * 8 / 9 + ")"); g.selectAll("rect") .data(color.range().map(function(color1) { var d = color.invertExtent(color1); if (d[0] == null) d[0] = x.domain()[0]; if (d[1] == null) d[1] = x.domain()[1]; return d; })) .enter().append("rect") .attr("height", 10) .attr("x", function(d) { return x(d[0]); }) .attr("width", function(d) { return x(d[1]) - x(d[0]); }) .style("fill", function(d) { return color(d[0]); }); item.title: "Travels"
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: Me at sunset at the Masai Mara Reserve in Kenya, hanging by a tree with a blue shirt on, with a Masai man in the foreground. (Yes, in which I photoshop myself onto this photo, by Jen Eudy.) The Masai Mara is a game reserve in Kenya, contiguous with the Serengeti in Tanzania. It is named after the Masai people, and "mara," meaning spotted in Maa (Masai language), owing to its spotted appearance, from the spots including from trees, scrubs, and cloud shadows. The Masai Mara has an exceptional population of lions, leopards, and cheetahs; it also has an annual migration of zebras, Thompson gazelles, wildebeasts, to and from the Serengeti, called the Great Migration. Me at a cafe on a street in Paris, with the Eiffel Tower in the background. (Oh yes, in which I photoshop myself onto this photo. The Eiffel Tower is named after Gustav Eiffel, whose company built and designed the tower. It was erected in 1889 as the entrance arch to the World's Fair, which would celebrate the centennial of the French Revolution. Parisian cafes are awesome, and are different from coffee shops as we think of them in the U.S. They have fully equipped kitchens and serve meals any time of the day, and have full bars and wine also. Me and the Sierra Nevada Mountains. (Yes, in which I photoshop myself onto this amazing photo on instagram.com/spono. The Sierra Nevada is a mountain range between California's Central Valley and the Basin and Great Basin Ranges. The Sierra is 400 miles north-to-south and 70 miles east-to-west. It includes Lake Tahoe, Mount Whitney (the highest point in the contiguous United States), and the Yosemite Valley.

item.title: World Literacy D3 Choropleth
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: http://www.khasachi.com/wppost/worldliteracy1.html This animated world map shows world literacy (CIA Factboook data). Literacy rates from lowest to highest are colored from green(lowest), purple (middle), to peach (highest). Light grey indicates no available data. The animation is in the following order: total population, male population, female population. The fantastic code was available, and beyond the color scale, I did very little customization -- so it was not difficult to put this together, but I've wanted to make a world map -- and so I did? I took the code straight from rgdonohue’s blocks on his animated map. I replaced the provided csv data that had random numbers and years as categories, with literacy data and categories as all, male, and female. The map shows what you would expect with higher literacy rates in certain parts of the world, and female literacy rates lower than male ones where the overall population had relatively lower literacy rates. The hardest part of this exercise for me was parsing the large JSON to get country names for the abbreviations provided in the csv. It was fun getting acquainted with JSON again, and I'm looking forward to finding that useful.

item.title: Bay Area Home Values
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: http://www.khasachi.com/BAZipsComp/BAzips2013.html http://www.khasachi.com/BAZipsComp/BAzips2008.html http://www.khasachi.com/BAZipsComp/BAzips2003.html http://www.khasachi.com/BAZipsComp/BAzips1998.html These choropleth maps (made with D3!) consist of annual averages for home values by zip code, for the Bay Area's 281 zip codes in its nine counties (San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Clara, Marin, Napa, Sonoma, Solano, Contra Costa, Alameda), for the specified years (five-year intervals with 2013 as the last year). (Mouseover areas to see zip codes, home values, and county). The color scheme is calculated based on the min and max values of the 2013, to provide a better comparison, rather than the min and max values for each year. I downloaded the zip code data as a shapefile from the Metropolitan Transportation Commission, and converted to a geojson, using GDAL and running ogr2ogr (apologies if I'm messing up the terminology here - instructions found here). The data is from Zillow, using the Zillow Home Value Index (ZHVI) for All Homes. Zillow's Home Value Index has the most granularity, at the zip code level, and does not include values of distressed homes: "Distressed sales are often reduced in price, and when they make up a larger portion of the market – as they have in recent years – can skew overall values wildly." These maps show that zip codes in the area referred to as the Silicon Valley has the highest home values, as does San Francisco. The map darkens in redness from 1998 to 2013. The darkest red, or highest home value in 2013, is zip code 94027, in Atherton, CA in San Mateo County, with a 2013 annual average home value of $4.2 million. The lowest 2013 annual average is $160,575 K in Richmond, CA in Contra Costa County. The following table shows annual average home values by county, for the years shown in the maps above: The following table shows the percentage changes between these five-year intervals by county: Interestingly, the biggest increases between years shown are from 1998 to 2003, with the largest increase, 96 percent, in Napa County. The largest increase from years 2008 to 2013 was 14 percent in Santa Clara County, located in the heart of the Silicon Valley. (What's left: putting this sucker up on GitHub, along with the geojson file.) And just for fun, here is the bigger version of the 2013 map: http://khasachi.com/BAZipsComp/BAzips2013big.html

item.title: Appearance
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: I worked on my last D3.js project two to three weeks ago, and put it up on bl.ocks here with code also on github here. Between that time and now, I had an two rounds of interviews with Hacker School in New York, and was not accepted. It was a long-shot, being a total novice to "programming" (quotes either because of impostor syndrome or because I am actually a programming impostor!). The first interview was a cinch, with about 15 minutes of conversation on Skype with a facilitator there. The second interview was so nerve-wracking for me. It basically took over everything else I was doing, between my many domestic responsibilities and any other projects I might have begun after the SF Bay Area choropleth. And here's why: it was a pair programming interview. Me?! Pair programming?! That was wild. I had never programmed professionally, and here I was going over my code with someone who's really good at this stuff? I decided to refactor a program I had written in Haskell (here), which creates basically a choropleth map, but I had done it last November from the ground-up, linking SVG coordinates to points to create lines, including Bezier curves, and several other complications. I decided to refactor that code instead of working on a D3.js project, because the instructions specifically said not to work on something that involved a framework. I hadn't looked at Haskell or my code since last December, and suddenly I had to remember everything I had done, and I had left myself about two days to do it. I got as prepared as I could; the interview proved that I really am not prepared for pair programming. I have gotten to where I am through sheer force of will, and without having very good fundamentals. The interview was quite embarrassing for me. BUT I do have to pat myself on the back for going through with 45 minutes of skype pair programming with someone who really knows their stuff. It's like I crossed some kind of weird line that suddenly showed up out of nowhere and dared me to cross it. It turns out, there's nothing on the other side but the experience had. Not totally true, though. Being forced to talk about something so awkwardly with someone for so long because I didn't really know the answers to questions I was being asked but it was kind of assumed I would, has made interactions with strangers way less daunting. Also, the experience forced me to realize how lacking in fundamentals I am. Since then, I have completed four weeks of the free CS101 online course with Stanford, and realizing this might not be rigorous enough, I've signed up for another class on object-oriented programming that will be for credit. I've changed the theme of this wordpress blog, using Isola as a springboard, and altering it to look more simple, and more like medium.com's layout. (It's still a work in progress because I want to change the menu page and a few other features.) I changed the theme's CSS to make the theme look like Isola, here: to look more like medium.com, here: I've other projects in place, which I will post here and elsewhere around the Internets in short order!

item.title: Data Visualization of Armed Conflict, 1946-2013
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: http://khasachi.com/nadine/conflictandregion.html This data visualization shows the number of armed conflicts by region, from 1946 to 2013 (68 years), with the circles' radii increasing with larger numbers of conflicts. It is also here, replete with code. Data The data is from the Uppsala Department of Peace and Conflict Research. I added a column called "Region" to the most recent (2013) UCDP/PRIO Armed Conflict Dataset, and coded the region of the Location provided in the dataset of the armed conflict. I coded the regions based on Wikipedia's Regions of the World template. If there was more than location for one conflict, I divided the conflict into equal parts per region. I used Excel's countifs function to count the number of conflicts by year and region, resulting in the csv file with the data. Code: My idea for this data visualization was to begin with something more basic -- a few circles, and build onto some complexity (rather than beginning with something complex, like this, and trying to understand it or change its features when I didn't fully understand it). I think this was a good idea for me. I customized this visualization and understand, not only d3.js more, but also JavaScript, which happens to be essential to learning D3. Reading through this presentation, and this presentation (which I found here), drove home the importance of knowing JavaScript but also the cool things one can do with D3 if they really understand it. (Here's a slide from the first presentation link.) I went through the Let's Make a Bar Chart tutorials to begin, and using the chart in Part III, I changed the rectangles to circles. The final result is much different from the starting point of the bar chart in Part III. Here is a summary of the major changes: - If statements to change the color of circles based on their regions. - A slider that would change the radii of the circles based on the number associated with each region and year. I used d3noob's example to add this element. - For loops to loop through all the years and update the circles' radii and labels based on the value of the slider element. - Removed the data labels using text.exit().remove(). I need help with this, because I don't really understand why I put it where I put it, and why the xaxis seems tied with it. If anyone has an explanation, that would be very welcome! Analysis of the Data: Asia has had the largest number of armed conflicts, followed by Africa, according to the data. These two regions also hold the two largest populations, in the same order. The following table shows each region's population as a percent of the total world population as of 2013, compared to the each region's number of conflicts as a percent of the total number of to the total number of conflicts, for three years: the first year of the data, 1946; the mid-point year of the data, 1980; and the final year of the data, 2013. The table illustrates that the percent of armed conflicts by region ties fairly closely with that region's percent of the total population. The major exception is Africa, which has had a higher percent of conflicts compared to the percent of its population to the world's population.

item.title: SKETCH OF ALFRED BARR'S DIAGRAM = "CUBISM AND ABSTRACT ART", 1955
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: http://www.khasachi.com/BarrDiagram/arcstuff5.html I used D3.JS to make this example of Alfred Barr's"Diagram of Stylistic Evolution from 1890 until 1935: Cubism and Abstract Art" as sketched by artist Ward Shelley, shown in Design for Information. The entire code is here. I used different shapes including: arcs, triangles, rectangles, lines, bezier curves; and six csv files with data for these shapes, to create the diagram. I wanted to make this diagram to learn to use basic shapes and D3JS, to have more understanding of the elements and basics, and be able customize visualizations more. Also, I'm fascinated with the evolution of art. I believe that, through this practice, I accomplished gaining a better grasp on the elements and shapes in svgs and how D3Js uses those elements to make data-driven visualizations. (Also, I gained what might be called an intimate relationship with the coordinate system: for example, see the CSV's with coordinates on my code on bl.ocks.org.) Here is the code for the different shapes, along with the csv files showing their coordinates and/or size: Lines: d3.csv("linedata.csv", function(error, data) { chart.selectAll("g") .data(data) .enter().append("line") .attr("x1", function(d) { return d.x1; }) .attr("y1", function(d) { return d.y1; }) .attr("x2", function(d) { return d.x2; }) .attr("y2", function(d) { return d.y2; }) .attr("stroke-width", 1) .attr("stroke", "black") .style("stroke-dasharray", function(d) { return ( d.dash1 + "," + d.dash2 ); }); }) * csv for Lines: arrow,x1,y1,x2,y2,dash1,dash2,id 1,135,5,110,0,0,0, 2,282,0,235,5,0,0, 3,112,140,80,37,0,0, 4,96,140,20,10,0,0, 5,123,135,190,40,0,0, ... etc for 50 lines Bezier Curves: d3.csv("curvecoords.csv", function(error, data) { chart.selectAll("g") .data(data) .enter().append("path") .attr("d", function(d) { return d.coords; }) .attr("stroke-width", 1) .attr("stroke", "black") .style("fill", "none") .style("stroke-dasharray", function(d) { return ( d.dash1 + "," + d.dash2 ); }) * csv for Bezier Curves: curve,coords,dash1,dash2,id 12,"M-10,97 A-5,10 0 0,0 -3,210",3,3, 16,"M360,150 A100,60 0 0,1 240,190",0,0, 16,"M240,190 A100,60 0 0,0 144,205",0,0, 18,"M386,200 A215,30 0 0,0 170,204",0,0, ...etc for several more curves Rectangles: d3.csv("rectData.csv", function(error, data) { chart.selectAll("g" ) .data(data) .enter().append("rect") .attr("class", "rect") .attr("x", function(d) { return d.x; }) .attr("y", function(d) { return d.y; }) .attr("width", function(d) { return d.width; }) .attr("height", function(d) { return d.height; }) * csv for Rectangles number,x,y,width,height,textX,textY,text 1,10,-10,100,20,14,3,JAPANESE PRINTS 2,-20,125,105,20,-18,138,NEAR EASTERN ART 3,200,157,110,20,207,170,NEGRO SCULPTURE 4,235,210,115,15,240,220,MACHINE AESTHETIC 5,120,405,115,35,155,420,MODERN 5,,,,,140,432,ARCHITECTURE Arcs: d3.csv("barrData.csv", function(error, data) { var arc = d3.svg.arc() .innerRadius(function(d) {return d.iRadius}) .outerRadius(function(d) {return d.oRadius}) .startAngle(2.0) .endAngle(4.2) ; chart.selectAll("g") .data(data) .enter().append("path") .style("fill", function(d, i){ return d.color; }) .attr("d", arc) .attr("transform", function(d) { return "translate(" + d.tranx + "," + d.trany + ")"; }); chart.selectAll("g") .data(data) .enter().append("text") .attr("class", "stuff") .attr("transform", function(d) { return "translate(" + (d.lPosx) + "," + (d.lPosy) + ")"; }) .text(function(d) { return d.label; }) .attr("text-anchor", "middle") *csv for Arcs: iRadius,oRadius,tranx,trany,label,lPosx,lPosy,color 30,31,70,9, VAN GOGH,70,20,black 45,46,188,-5, GAUGIN,188,20,black 70,71,440,-20, SEURAT,440,32,black 30,31,10,75, REDON,10,82,black 30,31,500,70,ROUSSEOU,500,80,black 35,36,110,160,FAUVISM,110,170,black ...etc for all the Arcs Downward-Facing Triangles: d3.csv("triDataDown.csv", function(error, data) { var triangleDown = d3.svg.symbol().type("triangle-down") /* triangles for arrow points */ chart.selectAll(".down-points") .data(data) .enter().append("path") .attr("class", "point") .attr("d", triangleDown) .attr("transform", function(d) { return "translate(" + d.dtriTransX + "," + d.dtriTransY + ")"; }); }) *csv for Downward-Facing Triangles: number,dtriTransX,dtriTransY,place 3,112,145,VG-Fauvism 4,95,145,JP-Fauvism 5,123,140,Sm-Fauvism 6,135,145,Cn-Fauvism 9,447,180,St-Cubism ...etc for all downward-facing triangles And now on to the subject of the diagram: Stylist Evolution from 1890 to 1950: Cubism and Abstract Art. It was awesome to go through this diagram and learn about the different movements, artists, and each of their influences on the descendents (at least Barr's interpretation/analysis of it). I should note that I've never taken an art history class, and so I took this as an opportunity to learn: more explicitly: I'm probably getting a lot wrong with understanding this diagram. This article was a great introduction to understanding the chart. Alfred Barr, who made this diagram, was the first director of the Museum of Modern Art. Barr made this diagram was made for an exhibit he curated there in 1936, called Cubism and Abstract Art. The diagram and the exhibit show abstract art, geometrical and non-geometrical, as the goal. From the article: "Cubism and Abstract Art together with the widespread dissemination of its influential catalogue, establishe dCubism as the central issue of early modernism, abstraction as the goal." (Side note: the non-art sources are in the red rectangles). Also, "These ideas dominated understanding of the early-twentieth developments in modernism for decades." For Barr, the exhibit was also political; Barr: "This essay and exhibition might well be dedicated to those painters of squares and circles (and the architects influenced by them) who have suffered at the hands of philistines with political power." Here is my attempt at a visual representation of this diagram through examples of the art in each category. I'm leaving out titles and artists out of interest of space and time. Maybe at some point I will write out descriptions of the movements/artists and titles of the paintings and artists, but that is too much time for and I go in order of the categories from left to right, until Cubism, when I follow those down to their different destinations, either non-geometrical or geometrical abstract art. My favorite group of art from these categories is strangely Seurat and Rousseou. They are beautiful and so sharp, bright, and at the same time so different. My favorite movement is Bauhaus, because of its heavy and deep influence on modern architecture and inspirational assignation of beauty to everyday objects. JAPANESE PRINTS VAN GOGH SYNTHETISM and GAUGIN CEZANNE NEO-IMPRESSIONISM and SEURAT ROUSSEOU REDON NEAR EASTERN ART FAUVISM EXPRESSIONISM NEGRO SCULPTURE MACHINE AESTHETIC BRANCUSI CUBISM ORPHISM FUTURISM DADAISM SURREALISM NON-GEOMETRICAL ABSTRACT ART ------------- Cubism to PURISM DE STIJL and NEOPLASTICISM BAUHAUS MODERN ARCHITECTURE GEOMETRICAL ABSTRACT ART ...back up to... SUPREMATISM CONSTRUCTIVISM GEOMETRICAL ABSTRACT ART (again)

item.title: BayBikes in App Store
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: My first iPhone app, BayBikes, is in the app store! https://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewSoftware?id=924787459&mt=8 Find out how many bikes and docks are available at stations in the Bay Area Bike Share system!

item.title: Learning to Program
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded:
I feel like I can more officially say that I'm learning to program now. I've been trying, for the past few years, with some months more intense than others, to very informally learn programming. My informal learning has included several online tutorials, attempts to go through a few books, and even some MOOCs. I've stuck with it because it's challenging, so useful, and I really enjoy it. And because my informal way of doing things has allowed me to get things done, albeit sometimes very frustratingly.
Now I feel like I'm officially learning it because I'm taking a Java class at a community college, and am in week 8 of it, and I'm learning so much. Before this class, I wouldn't have said that I was informally learning programming, because I thought what I was doing was pretty good and allowing me to make progress. But now I feel like I actually understand it so much more. It's great. And I want to do more.
It's taking up some of my time, and I had been in the beginning (first three lectures) part of trying to do the online course available through ITunes U, Developing iOS 7Apps for iPhone and iPad. I went back to it a few days ago, but had to start again from Lecture 1 because I needed the refresher. And oh my, after two months of this Java class that covers so much object-oriented knowledge needed for Objective-C, I understand these lectures so much more! I'm trying to find time to do go through these videos and complete the assignments on a regular basis, while still staying on top of the Java class, so that I don't lose the time investment to learn what I've learned from the Developing iOS class. I'm eager to begin my next project, but I need to slow down to learn more first, I think.

item.title: Studying for the Final
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded:
I'm studying for the Java class final now. I'm excited to have the break between this class and the Intermediate Java, and the C ++ class that starts in mid-January. I plan on completing an app and submitting it to the Apple app store during this break.
Regarding the Developing for IOS class that I started watching the lectures for on ITunes U, I've decided that, since it's not for credit, I can't trick myself into thinking it is. The Assignments have proven too difficult for me right now, and so I threw my hands up, completed the Assignment I was stuck on through someone's work on Github, and have decided to move on with the other lectures. I think after the intermediate Java class, I'll have enough knowledge to do the assignments in a reasonable amount of time, but it's not worth it for me to spend the time figuring it out right now. I'm really enjoying the lectures, regardless.

item.title: Woot!
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: I finished my final for the Java class early this morning, and now I'm done with the class - well, once I get the grades for it. But now I can focus my time on developing with iOS! I'm really excited about this. Oh, the possibilities!

item.title: Java Programmer!
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded:
The grades are up and I got an A in the Java class! I think my celebration will consist of calories in the form of a small cup of eggnog (okay, and RHOBH). It's great to have this feeling of accomplishment. :D
I'm going through the demo for one of the lectures for the Developing for iOS class on ITunes U (by Stanford). So excited to start on my next iOS project.

item.title: CS193P
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: On Lecture 11 of CS 193P from the 2013-14 academic year. Who knew this would be so much fun?! I'm loving iOS development.

item.title: Your Congress is in the App Store
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: My newest app, Your Congress, is now in the app store! Yay!!

item.title: Web Development
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: I've begun to dip the tippy tops of my toes into web development over the past week, during my time off from completing my C++ and Intermediate Java classes, until my course on advanced data structures and algorithms in Java begins. I watched the Web Design Fundamentals videos on Lynda.com, and am developing a plan of action. I'm really looking forward to learning more, recording my progress here, and best of all, putting it into practice. Every time I gain more programming skills, I think, I'm so excited about THIS. But really, I am so excited about learning web development -- it's what I first tried out those many, many years ago with HTML before CSS, before blogs, on Geocities, with my hardcore Beastie Boys fan page (replete with mouseover scrolling!). There are aspects of mobile development and Java that I love too, and I'm just getting my feet wet. But I'm so looking forward to it and making things with my new skills. Other news: I saw Bill Nighy (currently on Broadway in Skylight) and Paul Hegarty, of the iPhone Application Development course fame (plus, I'm sure, many, many, more, more useful things) in the past two days. I only fangirled one of them, interrupting their walk down the street (hint: his online lectures helped me develop an app).

item.title: Java and Computer Science
item.dc:creator: khasachi
item.content:encoded: I've just begun taking the Advanced Data Structures and Algorithms in Java class this week. I'm doing the readings for the first week. Let's just say this: it will be challenging. Web Development might be put on the back-burner while I delve more into computer science (rather than computer programming). I'm nervous.
